awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Toward a Dependable Network of Batteryless Intermittent Nodes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores the software and hardware foundations that enable dependable communications between networks of batteryless sensor nodes powered solely by ambient energy (energy harvesting). This is particularly challenging since such batteryless nodes usually have intermittent operation, spending a large fraction of their time without sufficient power to operate, depending on the ambient energy conditions. This project will explore two thrusts: (1) developing approaches to establish initial communications between batteryless nodes and (2) developing methods to efficiently maintain communications across periods of no power by developing a shared sense of time between batteryless nodes.

Enabling direct communications between batteryless sensor nodes allows development of large-scale networks of batteryless intermittent nodes where two nodes at any location can dependably communicate with each other as long as the network is connected. Such a network of batteryless nodes can be deployed across large areas (e.g., fields, factories, space) and self-sustain without wiring or battery changes to monitor events. The result enables transformative improvements to applications demanding pervasive, long-lived, and autonomous intelligent sensing systems, including industrial automation, infrastructure monitoring, agriculture, environmental sciences, healthcare, defense, and space exploration. The resulting software and hardware systems along with collected energy data of this project will be made publicly available for scientists, engineers, educators, and industry to use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to establish the software and hardware foundations to enable dependable communication between batteryless intermittent sensor nodes powered solely by energy harvesting. Communication between batteryless nodes is particularly challenging due to their intermittent operation -- batteryless nodes spend a large fraction of their time without sufficient power to operate and have limited direct control over the timing of operation due to variations in ambient energy conditions. An outcome of this project is the introduction of an intermittency-aware network stack abstraction (i.e., netstack). This includes adding the concepts and initial abstractions of lifecycle management protocols, shared sense of time, and intermittency-aware link layers to the nascent field of intermittent sensor node communication. In aggregate, this netstack advances the area of batteryless intermittent networks by providing mechanisms to establish initial communications between batteryless nodes and maintain link-level communication using multiple hardware and software mechanisms. 


In terms of broader impacts, this project yielded open-sourced hardware and software prototypes of communication primitives for batteryless sensor nodes and a calibrated simulator for networks of batteryless nodes. Educationally, five PhD students, two MS students, and eight REU students gained research mentorship as part of this project. Modules relating to developing sensor node systems and batteryless systems were integrated into three courses and six capstone design projects enabling undergraduate students to delve deeper into embedded system design.


Last Modified: 01/14/2025
Modified by: Henry Duwe
